samples.transcript_original: Given the chance to purchase a new vehicle, I would really love to buy a red Jeep Wrangler because I really like this car and I can go on adventure with it and it would be easy to find in a parking lot. That is the end of part one. We will now continue with part two.

samples.question: Have you ever lost a wallet?
samples.transcript: Yes, and that was a very unfortunate story. so I remember I was in 10th grade, I think. I was at this bubble tea shop and, when I left, I totally forgot about my wallet. five minutes later, I suddenly remembered, about it and I came back to the shop to, to ask about the wallet. it was nowhere to be found. thank God I did not lose much money, but it was such a hassle to just go through all of the paperwork again for my ID card.

samples.question: Do you smile when you are having a photo?
samples.transcript: I try to. I try to. But you know, sometimes you have got to give that, that steely, the blue steel look I think it is called. that is the one. A pose. A pose. I am going to give you a topic and I would like you to talk about it for one to two minutes. The only piece of feedback that I would give to Saskia here is that at times some of her answers are a little bit short and I feel that she could elaborate a little bit more on her answers. For example, she talked about whether people smile in photographs. And she could say, well yeah, I tend to smile often in photographs, but I suppose it depends on the situation. If it is an active photograph and we are, doing something, then maybe there is no chance to smile. But she did, use a word which I am not that familiar with, but I am not doubting her. It was a blue steel smile. I do not really use that phrase very often, but I think it is probably true. You can talk about having a steely complexion, which means that you are quite stern and you do not always smile. So somebody who has a steely complexion might not smile so often.

samples.question: And are there any differences between your favorite favorite meeting places now and when you were a child?

Therefore the meeting place would also have to change as well. From playground to I guess popular street or a popular meeting place. Yeah. samples.question: And what kind of new things do you think elderly people should learn?
samples.transcript: Elderly people. So like, I think, one important thing for elderly people to learn, though I do not want to sound condescending in any way, would be to, I guess, accept, or I guess, go with the flow of the modern society. I think a lot of people kind of get stuck in the past and thinking this is how it used to be and now we have to put that on our children and make sure they live a certain way as well. But I think it is important for them to learn and evaluate the current situation and see the course of history, I guess, and how things are, how things are changing and kind of adopting to that and not restricting their student, I mean, restricting their children in any way of saying you have to stay in this tiny little box, but also allow them to, try different things as well. And so that is a new skill, I guess, for them to learn. Okay, perfect. That will do us. Thank you very much. that is it. Alright, so.

samples.question: And do you usually use a card or cash?

samples.question: Alright, so could you describe a time when you found an item that someone else lost?
samples.transcript: So, I found a wallet near Gyeongbokgung. It was about two years ago. I found it near a bench in front of Gyeongbokgung. And when I found it, I asked my friend if we should take it to a near police station. But we are really worried because right before going to Gyeongbokgung, we saw a news about lost and found items fraud. Because in the news, someone like picked a wallet that someone just like put somewhere and there were like drugs in it. Yeah, and the person who collected the wallet got into a serious problem. So we were worried we might go through similar stuff. So we discussed what we should do about the wallet, but we decided to take it because the wallet seemed really fine and it was not a fabric wallet. It was one of those see-through wallets, you know, like very clear with like made out of rubber. So, it would be just safe to like take it and put it at the police station. So, yeah, that is exactly what I did. Very nice. that is a minute and 20 seconds total. Okay.

samples.question: Is there a good way to give constructive feedback to someone about something?
samples.transcript: Yes, I definitely think there is and this is something that I have learned about in one of the courses I am studying at uni too, which was about sports coaching. So how we can give constructive feedback and help our students to learn to learn from their mistakes. And I think it is really important when giving constructive feedback to say something positive first, to make sure you are not too negative and that you do not have a negative tone to your voice, that you are happy. and that you are just generally trying to help them. You want to give off the vibe that you are just trying to help them and not that you are trying to put them down. I think it is one of the worst things when someone's telling you something and you know they are just trying to let you down and trying to make you feel bad about yourself. So I always try and start with something positive and then say, how about we try this or how about next time you do this? I think always phrasing it as a question is also a more sensitive way to approach the topic. In pronunciation there is a feature of, of language which is called the weak form. The weak form is when we do not put the stress on the, the word. And if you go back and listen to Romy, she very often uses the weak form of the sound to, to see, to do. We do not say to see or to do, we say to see, to do. And she uses this weak form with this sound called the schwa, the a sound, the t-t-t, to see, to do, to watch, to sing. And you will notice that she uses the weak form really well.

samples.question: What type of shoes do you usually wear?
samples.transcript: I wear sandals because you don need socks for sandals and it easier to wear and it comfortable and also I wear sneakers as well because I do a lot of sports like fencing badminton so I need sneakers for that we are on to a new topic now which is shoes. You may get this topic in your test so be prepared for a topic like this. Now in her answer she said I wear sandals because you do not need socks for sandals and that is a compound sentence but she is explaining the reason why, Which is wonderful. I really like that. And then she starts, these little errors start slipping through. She said, and it is easy, easier to wear and it is comfortable. And the problem here is that she is referring to the wrong type of noun. She is referring to a singular noun. And actually she is talking about sandals. And the correct form, the correct pronoun there should be they are easier to wear and they are, they are more comfortable. And so she is mixing up the singulars and plurals there. But then she redeemed herself and she says, because I do a lot of sport. Notice there how she is changed the because to because. Because I do a lot of sport and lots of people think that the IELTS speaking test is a formal test and that you cannot contract words, you cannot shorten words. Well that is actually a myth and the word cause is absolutely appropriate and acceptable in the test. So I encourage you, if you can use it naturally, then definitely think about that. Then she is used words like sneakers. I, I also, she said also I wear sneakers as well. She is actually repeating two cohesive devices there. She is using also and as well together. Probably one of them would be redundant and she said like fencing and badminton. Good start. I am just a little bit concerned about these little grammar slips that are coming through.

samples.question: Is it important for you to wear comfortable shoes?

But again, a few problems with, the wrong subject and verb. She said, the most important thing for me is comfortable. And what she is done there is she is used an adjective in the place where there should have been a noun. The most important thing for me is that they are comfortable, not it is comfortable. So, and also, that would be a complex sentence. You could replace it with a noun and you could say, The most important thing for me is comfort. samples.question: Homes in the future?
samples.transcript: That is a good question. Let me see. If you mean ten or twenty years from now, I do not think they will be that different to what we have now. samples.question: What do you usually do on the weekend?

samples.question: Describe a creative solution you found to a problem.
samples.transcript: Working as a hotel manager, I face problems every single day. I had this experience where a VIP guest just checked in. We thought everything was smooth, everything was okay. But then in a couple of minutes, I saw one bad feedback in Google reviews saying like, the staff was not that much helpful. The staff was not smiling. And so one bad comment would definitely affect the image of the property. Me being the hotel manager, I always go to an easy solution, which is being more personalized and reaching myself to the guest. What I did was to give the guest a call in the room, check if the family was checked in well, if there is anything that she need, and point out about the review that she just posted in our property, about our property. And then ask her what made her feel that way What made her post that comment or that review in our website And I will always try to put myself in the shoe of the guest to understand more where they coming from and for me to be able to give a proper solution to her problem And I think the most creative solution in hospitality industry in dealing with complaints is being more personalized and just be yourself and have that connection with your guests. Like treat them as family. Because with that, I think it is easier to solve the issue. So we have been talking about creativity and solving problems in a creative way and we are going to continue to talk about that.

samples.question: And then you, why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you, it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking, let us call it Filipino English for many, many years. And no one has ever said that is an error. But when you do the IELTS test, again, you are moving to an English speaking country. They will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of. So for example, staff was not that much helpful. It should have been the staff were not very helpful. Or every household in Philippines, there is really gardens. Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. Yeah. there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subject verb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for example, let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get about six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences, you would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small, just small little errors in most sentences, so you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students, and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent. But this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall, you would be in and around 6.5 or 7 overall. Now for most people, 7 is, is, great for, from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My, advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before, a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you, you do not know you have, you are even making them. It does not affect communication. So it is not a huge issue. It just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

samples.transcript: That is really important. try to paint a clear well ststructured not a confusing but a well ststructured picture in your listener's mind using adjectives, adverbs and different kinds of sensory language. language that talks about the senses, how something feels, how something smells, how something tastes, how something looks, and how something sounds. Of course, use compound complex language. If you want to get a score over six, you cannot just use simple sentences. You have to join the sentences with conjunctions like and, nor, but, for, so, therefore, since, when, if, however, so on. So, review your conjunctions if you are not sure. And of course, use adjective clauses. Adjective clauses are a big part of the descriptive language. Now these three elements are related to each other. So when your language is complex, it also becomes more coherent. when your language is more natural again it is more coherent. when it is more complex it is more natural. So that is why you see these circles joined because complexity, coherence and natural language they each depend on each other. So as you improve one area, you improve the other areas. So work on each area individually and then combine them. So again, as I mentioned with this candidate, coherence is quite high. samples.question: Are you ready?
samples.transcript: Let us jump straight into part one of the speaking test. In part one, the examiner will begin by introducing themselves, then asking you to state your name and show your identification. Then, they will ask you three sets of questions about familiar topics. The first set usually asks you general questions about yourself, such as your work or study, your home, or the place where you live. The second and third sets are personal questions about familiar topics like the food you like, your hobbies, people you spend time with, and so on. you will get up to 12 questions in this part, and it is important to know how to answer them well in the time given. But do not worry, today you will only get four part one questions. Here are my tips for part one. First, give extended answers. As a general rule, I would say try to talk for around 20 seconds for each answer. that is the equivalent of about two to three written sentences. Try to add more information to your response, such as giving an example or a reason to explain your answer. Also, make sure your answers have complete sentences. do not just give single word answers. Finally, there are no right or wrong answers to the questions, but what you say should answer the question. Now, it is time for you to try part one. I am going to ask you one set of questions, and you will have 20 seconds to answer each. And to get the most out of today's practice test, I recommend you record your answers so you can go back and check how you went.

samples.question: If it is online, will I send it to home or something?
samples.transcript: What if I lose my internet connection while speaking and they cannot hear me?" I had the same worries and anxieties as you when I found out I had to take the IELTS Speaking test via Zoom.
samples.transcript_original: What if I lose my internet connection while speaking and they can't hear me?" I had the same worries and anxieties as you when I found out I had to take the IELTS Speaking test via Zoom.

samples.question: However, my experience in the recent test went quite smoothly, so I made this video to share it with you.
samples.transcript: Let us watch together! When taking the IELTS Speaking test via Zoom, first, we 'll be called into a small room by the coordinator, similar to when you take the IELTS FaceTime test. there is already a laptop connected to the screen. Once connected, you can sit back and relax. let us start the test! So now they will ask me if I heard clearly, and you can adjust the volume in the lower part of the microphone I am wearing. I can increase or decrease the volume if I can hear clearly or feel it is too loud. The special thing is that when speaking, during the scene I just experienced in January, I still remember wearing a mask. Everyone else was saying, "Why, it is an online exam?" it is true that I did not see the person watching in person, and I still wore a mask. The reason I received was that this is for safety reasons. The microphone used during the exam is shared among the candidates, so you should wear a mask to protect yourself and those around you. Before entering the exam room, the staff reminded me that if, during the exam, for any reason, I could not hear the answer clearly, or I could andt hear a word clearly, I could ask again. I see that they repeat the questions for me, and this will not completely affect my score. Yeah, I am pretty reassured about that. Next, there will always be people standing outside, and if there is any problem, I just have to knock on the door and they 'll come in to help me during the Speaking section of the exam. So, Maximark will ask me directly as usual. But others will share their screens via a mouth-reading app, and that makes it quite clear to read. that is all; everything goes very normally. My speaking will be automatically recorded on the exam board's system, so you do not have to press any buttons or anything during the exam. You just have to do what you need to do to speak. And after you have finished your practice, you just stand there and leave. I spat it out, stood up, and went outside. Then I was in charge. The coordinator reminded me to check if my exam file was okay after about 3 to 5 minutes. If it was okay, I would proceed to hand it over to her, and that was it. If you need it, you can keep it simple like that. This is the zoom screen that will appear when you enter the exam room. I am only allowed to sit here, and I will be on the screen like this. I have placed this camera somewhere, and on this side is the spinner screen. Of course, I 'll also turn on the camera. I am just giving an example. And the thing is, I just sit here and speak very normally. that is my experience when I took the IELTS Speaking online via Zune last January. I went to Ngoc Khanh beach, and I hope that through this video, you will feel a little more at ease about what to do if you register for the IELTS exam in the future. I am not a fan of IELTS, but I think the most important thing when I passed was to be confident in myself and just go into the exam room and express myself. that is all I need. I wish you all a great exam experience! Bye.

samples.question: It is a test, right?
samples.transcript: If you have ever had a driving test or a job interview, you you probably come out of those things thinking like, "damn it. I I did not I did not do as well as I know I can do." And it is the same with the IELTS test that we always feel like I could have done better. I should have done better. I should not have said that. I should have said this, I should not have done that, I should have done this. it is a test. we and it always happens unfortunately. so yeah, in terms of language ability, the candidate certainly can get a nine. it is just a question of whether she can hold it together on test day. I I do not know if she is planning to take another IELTS test soon. I know she is done some IELTS tests in the past. I would say, you know, on the one hand, I would say forget about the nine. You do not need the nine. You do not need to prove anything to anyone. you you have mastered the English language. does not make any difference whether you get a nine or not. samples.question: [Transcript chunk 2]
samples.transcript: Have to confess that i procrastinate a lot and it is due to this very bad habit of mine that I am sometimes swamped with deadlines and there was this one time when it got you know so hectic that i could barely catch a breath which was when i had to simultaneously juggle my research project and my graduation thesis so as i mentioned my university major does not have anything to do with my job which involves the teaching and the learning of english and for me who is always wanted to become an established teacher one of the prerequisites for my master's degree would be to have experience in this domain and in an attempt to fulfill this condition i took on a small scale study on the subject of learners autonomy in a local university and it is just so happened to coincide with the submission deadline of my thesis paper and to make matters worse i also had evening classes to teach i could not afford to underperform so we tried to plan everything to a t the am the morning was solely dedicated to my research which involved gathering interpreting and consolidating data and in the afternoon i rushed to finish my dissertation while squeezing in some time for lesson planning as well in the end all my efforts yielded wonderful results i was ecstatic to find that both of my papers were published in i think two scientific journals and i even got admitted into my dream university in the uk yeah okay that is the end of part two in the next part of the test we are going to discuss more about pressure and technology so does technology put more pressure on life it is the opposite actually technology in fact takes away the more burdens.

samples.question: [Transcript chunk 3]
samples.transcript: Some aspects for day-to-day tasks a good example is let us see meal prepping in the past it used to take a lot of time to put together a simple meal these days the advent of microwaves and air fryers affords people you know the luxury of creating delicious dishes in a matter of minutes so what can be concluded is that life has become much less stressful with the help of smart devices all right how important is it to get work life balance well this matter is a bit of a head scratcher to me of course it is ideal to reach a state of equilibrium where both are equally prioritized simply put if one gets carried away with work and neglects his family and friends and himself that person will risk jeopardizing his own mental health which means he cannot work as effectively and on the contrary those who are too carefree and fun-loving will not get far in life since they do not spare enough time nor effort for professional development and i think striking a balance between career and leisure is therefore key to a happy life is it harder or easier to get work-life balance in the future given how the given how popular the hustle culture is getting i would say it is the former you know the job market is growing more competitive every passing day and so many people especially the young ones are willing to put in the extra hours to increase their net worth sometimes at the expense of their own personal priorities middle-aged employees are no exception and in countries with strong work ethics like japan over working to the point of self neglect is actually a serious matter thank you that is the end of your speaking test vocab.

samples.question: That grammar error becomes ingrained and then you go and do an IELTS test or you move to an English-speaking country and then you why do people think that I am making mistakes or why am I getting a lower score?
samples.transcript: Because to you it sounds totally fine because you have been speaking let us call it Filipino English for many many years and no one has ever said that is an error but when you do the IELTS test again you are moving to an English-speaking country they will pick up on those errors that you are completely unaware of so for example staff was not that much helpful it should have been the staff were not very helpful or every household in Philippines there is really gardens Instead of in every household in the Philippines, there are gardens. I know exactly what you are saying. >> there is no problem with meaning, but there are a lot of those little, for example, subjectverb agreement issues, article issues. there is some tense inconsistencies. So, the way that the IELTS examiner will think about your grammar score is number of sentences with or without errors. So for let us say just using round numbers, let us say you spoke 100 sentences. If more than 50 of those sentences had grammatical errors in them, more than half, you would get a band six for grammar. If more than 50 of those sentences had zero errors, those would be known as error-free sentences. You would get at least a band seven. In my opinion, there were more small just small little errors in most sentences. So you would get a band six for grammar. This is extremely common for Filipino students and this is one of the main reasons why they get 6.5. So their fluency is great. They answer the questions. Their vocabulary is quite good. Their pronunciation is excellent but this grammar issue brings them down. That should be your main area of focus. So overall you would be in and around 6.5 or seven overall. Now, for most people, seven is is great for from whatever they need to do. but 6.5 is often not good. depends on what you want to do. My advice would be to really focus on grammar and that can be quite difficult because as I said before a lot of these issues are ingrained because you have been making those errors for years and you you do not know you you are even making them. It does not affect communication so it is not a huge issue. It it just depends on what score you are hoping to get.

samples.question: You also used the structure " the last time I bought was two months ago." Do you remember that answer?
samples.transcript: I remember, but I am missing something. I am missing the object, "the last time I bought a pen," or "bought a pencil," not "the last time I bought." it is missing the object that comes after the verb, so try to remember the noun that follows it later. there is also a mistake: "When I was a child, I have care- free and stress-free." These two words are adjectives, so you should use " was to be" with the adjective to make sense. "I was care-free," "I was stress-free." But in terms of word usage, these two words are very good. Then, "my mom make sure," and then " ensuring" are redundant. Just " my mom make sure that we get the best deal" or "mom ur" is fine; you cannot use either one. Also, when you speak quickly, I notice that you tend to put the subject with the verb. The verb " in" is missing one part: the verb "to be" is missing, and you need to use the present simple tense for it to be correct. For example, when talking about a habit like "my mother always does this," you might say "She always managing," but that is not correct.

You have to join the sentences with conjunctions like and, nor, but, for, so, therefore, since, when, if, however, so on. So, review your conjunctions if you are not sure. So when your language is complex, it also becomes more coherent. when your language is more natural again it is more coherent. when it is more complex it is more natural. So that is why you see these circles joined because complexity, coherence and natural language they each depend on each other. So as you improve one area, you improve the other areas.
